stem: The nurse is caring for a 78-year-old male patient with a pressure ulcer on his coccyx. After reviewing the patient's EHR, including the nurse's notes, vital signs, lab results, physical exam findings, care plan, and medication administration record, the nurse must determine the appropriate actions, the most likely condition, and the parameters to monitor. Based on the information provided, select the most appropriate option from each category.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 07:00: Patient reports discomfort in coccyx area. Dressing intact, no visible drainage noted. Repositioned patient to left side. 09:00: Noted small area of non-blanchable erythema on coccyx during bath. Skin intact. Patient denies pain. 11:00: Wound care consult requested. 13:00: Wound care nurse assessed coccyx area: 2 cm x 2 cm area of non-blanchable erythema, intact skin. Stage I pressure ulcer documented. Hydrocolloid dressing applied. Patient educated on pressure relief techniques. 15:00: Patient tolerated dressing change well. Encouraged to shift weight every 2 hours. 17:00: Patient denies pain. Dressing remains intact. Area assessed, no changes noted. 19:00: Patient repositioned. Coccyx area assessed, dressing intact. Patient resting comfortably. 21:00: Patient voiced concerns regarding slow healing. Reassured and provided further education. 23:00: Dressing in place, dry and intact.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Alert and oriented x3. Skin: 2 cm x 2 cm area of non-blanchable erythema on coccyx with intact skin. No drainage or odor noted. Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, normoactive bowel sounds. Neurological: Gross motor and sensory intact.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
• Assess pressure ulcer daily for changes in size, color, and drainage.
  • Apply hydrocolloid dressing to coccyx pressure ulcer per wound care protocol.
  • Reposition patient every 2 hours.
  • Encourage adequate hydration and nutrition.
  • Consult with wound care specialist.

actions.text: Elevate the head of the bed to 45 degrees

topicTags: Pressure Ulcer Staging and Wound Care

rationale.correct: Correct actions are implementing pressure redistribution strategies to prevent further tissue damage and applying a transparent film dressing to protect the intact skin and promote a moist wound healing environment. The correct parameters to monitor are wound size and characteristics to assess for progression or improvement and patient's pain level to manage discomfort and evaluate the effectiveness of interventions. The patient has a Stage I pressure ulcer, defined by non-blanchable erythema of intact skin.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect actions include debriding the wound, which is not indicated for intact skin, and elevating the head of the bed to 45 degrees, which can increase pressure on the coccyx. Incorrect parameters to monitor include serum albumin levels, which are indicative of nutritional status but not directly related to short-term wound changes, and urine output, which is not directly relevant to the local wound environment.

answerBreakdown.rationale: Pressure redistribution is crucial to prevent further tissue breakdown and promote healing in pressure ulcers. Repositioning, specialized mattresses, and cushions are examples of these strategies.
Transparent film dressings protect the skin from friction and shear while allowing visualization of the wound. They are appropriate for Stage I pressure ulcers with intact skin.
Debridement is the removal of necrotic tissue and is not indicated for Stage I pressure ulcers with intact skin. Debridement is typically reserved for Stage III or IV ulcers with slough or eschar.

answerBreakdown.content: Elevate the head of the bed to 45 degrees
answerBreakdown.rationale: Elevating the head of the bed can increase pressure on the sacrum and coccyx, potentially worsening the pressure ulcer. While elevation might be indicated for respiratory issues, it should be minimized to prevent pressure ulcer complications.

Deep tissue injury is characterized by a purple or maroon localized area of discolored intact skin or blood-filled blister due to damage of underlying soft tissue from pressure and/or shear. While the patient has an area of discoloration, it is described as erythema and not a deep tissue injury.
A Stage I pressure ulcer is characterized by non-blanchable erythema of intact skin. This aligns with the assessment findings described in the scenario.

A Stage II pressure ulcer involves partial-thickness skin loss with exposed dermis. The ulcer presents as a shallow open ulcer with a red-pink wound bed, without slough. The scenario describes intact skin, ruling out Stage II.

An unstageable pressure ulcer involves full-thickness tissue loss in which the base of the ulcer is covered by slough (yellow, tan, gray, green or brown) and/or eschar (tan, brown or black) in the wound bed. The scenario describes intact skin, ruling out an unstageable ulcer.

Monitoring wound size and characteristics (e.g., color, drainage) is essential to assess for progression, improvement, or signs of infection. This provides objective data on the wound's healing status.
Assessing and managing pain is crucial for patient comfort and adherence to treatment. Changes in pain level can indicate changes in the wound condition.

While albumin levels are important for overall nutritional status and wound healing, they are not the most immediate or specific parameter to monitor for a Stage I pressure ulcer. Albumin levels reflect long-term nutritional status rather than acute wound changes.
Urine output is important for overall fluid balance but is not directly related to the local wound environment or the immediate management of a Stage I pressure ulcer.

clinicalPearls: Early identification and intervention are key to preventing the progression of pressure ulcers.
Pressure redistribution is the cornerstone of pressure ulcer prevention and treatment.
Thorough skin assessments should be performed regularly, especially in high-risk patients.

questionTrap.trap: Many students focus on advanced wound care techniques, overlooking the importance of basic interventions for early-stage pressure ulcers.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize foundational nursing principles, such as pressure redistribution and skin protection, before considering more complex interventions.

mnemonic.title: SKIN
mnemonic.expansion: Surface assessment, Keep moving, Incontinence management, Nutrition
